desc: The station regularly monitors key parameters such as dissolved oxygen (DO), pH, biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), nutrients, and temperature. These indicators help determine whether the water can support aquatic life and meet environmental standards.

Data collected from Station I helps LLDA evaluate pollution levels and identify trends related to domestic wastewater and surface runoff. The results support decision-making for pollution control and sustainable lake management.
The station measures water quality parameters including DO, pH, BOD, nitrate, and phosphate, which are important for tracking eutrophication and nutrient loading in the lake.

Station I is located in the Central West Bay of Laguna de Bay, an area influenced by nearby urban communities and commercial activities. This part of the lake receives runoff from surrounding cities and is important for assessing the effects of urban development on lake water quality.

Station II is situated in the East Bay of Laguna de Bay, an area influenced by agricultural lands and river inflows such as the Pagsanjan River system. This location is critical for monitoring nutrient input from upstream areas.

Station IV is located in the Central Bay, near the deeper and more open portion of Laguna de Bay. It represents general lake conditions and serves as a reference point for overall water quality assessment.
Station V is found in the Northern West Bay, an area close to highly populated and industrialized zones. This makes it important for monitoring pollution pressures from nearby communities.
Station XV is located near Taytay, Rizal, along the West Bay of Laguna de Bay. This area is influenced by rivers, shoreline settlements, and commercial activities.
Station XVI is positioned near Santa Rosa, Laguna, another key area along the West Bay. This location reflects the impact of residential, industrial, and commercial growth in Laguna province.
Station XVII is located within a designated fish sanctuary in the Central Bay of Laguna de Bay. This station is important for protecting aquatic life and biodiversity.
Station XVIII is located near Pagsanjan, Laguna, in the East Bay area where major rivers discharge into the lake. This makes it critical for monitoring river-borne pollutants.
